question: Question_A_20
sols:
The absolute value (or modulus) of a complex number $a+bi$ is

\begin{align*}r = \sqrt{a^2+b^2}=\sqrt{(-1)^2+1^2}=\sqrt 2\end{align*} and the argument,
$\theta$, is the angle between the right side of the $x$-axis and the
position of the complex number on the plane. In this case, the argument
is $3\pi /4$. To see that, you can either just visually see that the
point (-1,1) is clearly on the diagonal of the second quadrant of the
plane, or using trigonometry have

\begin{align*}\cos(\theta)=\frac{a}{r}=\frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}} \quad\text{and}\quad \sin(\theta)=\frac{b}{r}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\end{align*}
and from there notice that the corresponding angle is $3\pi /4$ (or in
real life compute the angle using a calculator since you only know a
very few values of sine and cosine).

So this allows us to write our complex number in polar form as

\begin{align*}-1+i=re^{\theta i}=\sqrt 2 e^{3\pi i/4}\end{align*}
hints:
Representing a complex number in the plane; can you geometrically
describe what are the values $r$ and $\theta$?

To follow on the previous hint:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $r$ is the modulus (or absolute value) of a complex number and
  represents its distance to the origin.
\item
  $\theta$ is the argument of a complex number and represents the angle
  between the line joining the point to the origin and the positive real
  axis.
\end{itemize}

See
\href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_number\#Absolute_value_and_argument}{the
Wikipedia entry for absolute value and argument of a complex number}.
